questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with complaints of drooping of the right upper eyelid, constriction of the right pupil, and lack of sweating on the right side of the face. On further questioning, the patient admits to experiencing neck pain following a minor car accident a week ago. Physical examination confirms the presence of ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis on the right side of the face. What is the most likely site of the lesion?

options.label: C
options.text: Pancoast tumor at the apex of the lung

options.label: D
options.text: Lesion of the superior orbital fissure

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents to the clinic with the complaints of right sided weakness and difficulty speaking. His speech is slow, effortful, and fragmented with short sentences, but his comprehension is not affected. Which of the following type of aphasia is this patient suffering from?

A 48-year-old male presents with acute onset weakness of the right side of the body. On examination: Right-sided complete hemiplegia Right-sided ptosis and dilated pupil Eye deviated outward and downward No sensory deficits Normal consciousness level Which type of hemiplegia is most likely in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Type of Hemiplegia

Location

Key Features

Additional Details

Weber's Hemiplegia

Midbrain (crus cerebri)

CN III palsy + contralateral hemiplegia

Ptosis, dilated pupil, outward/downward eye deviation

Medial Medullary Hemiplegia

(Option B ruled out)

Medial medulla

CN XII palsy + contralateral hemiplegia

Tongue deviation to ipsilateral side

Millard-Gubler Hemiplegia

(Option C ruled out)

Pons

CN VI, VII palsy + contralateral hemiplegia

Facial weakness and lateral rectus palsy

Pure Motor Hemiplegia

(Option D ruled out)

Internal capsule

Only motor deficits

No cranial nerve involvement

Cortical Level Hemiplegia

Motor cortex (precentral gyrus)

Segmental weakness, often associated with cortical signs

MCA territory most commonly involved

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with dizziness, difficulty swallowing, and right-sided facial numbness. On examination, she has ataxia, and when asked to stick out her tongue, it deviates to the right. Additionally, she experiences nystagmus and has a diminished gag reflex. What type of stroke is this patient most likely experiencing?
questions.explanation:
Medial Medullary Syndrome

(Option D ruled out)

Lateral Medullary Syndrome (Wallenberg Syndrome)

On side of lesion

  • Paralysis with atrophy of one-half half the tongue: Ipsilateral twelfth nerve

On side of lesion

  • Pain, numbness, impaired sensation over one-half the face: Descending tract and nucleus fifth nerve
  • Ataxia of limbs, falling to side of lesion: Restiform body, cerebellar hemisphere, cerebellar fibers, spinocerebellar tract
  • Nystagmus, diplopia, oscillopsia, vertigo, nausea, vomiting: Vestibular nucleus
  • Horner’s syndrome (miosis, ptosis, decreased sweating): Descending sympathetic tract
  • Dysphagia, hoarseness, paralysis of palate, paralysis of vocal cord, diminished gag reflex: Issuing fibers ninth and tenth nerves
  • Loss of taste: Nucleus and tractus solitarius
  • Numbness of ipsilateral arm, trunk, or leg: Cuneate and gracile nuclei
  • Weakness of lower face: Genuflected upper motor neuron fibers to ipsilateral facial nucleus

On side opposite lesion

  • Paralysis of arm and leg, sparing face; impaired tactile and proprioceptive sense over one-half the body: Contralateral pyramidal tract and medial lemniscus

On side opposite lesion

  • Impaired pain and thermal sense over half the body, sometimes face: Spinothalamic tract

questions.text: A 72-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after he collapsed at his home, and the neurologist suspects a medullary stroke after a thorough evaluation. Which of the following is NOT a feature of a medullary stroke?

options.label: D
options.text: Ipsilateral facial pain and loss of temperature sensation

questions.text: A 58-year-old man is admitted to the hospital after suddenly collapsing at home. Upon examination, he is fully conscious and aware of his surroundings but is unable to move any limbs or speak. He shows no signs of respiratory distress but struggles with swallowing and cannot perform any voluntary movements, except for blinking and vertical eye movements. What condition is this patient most likely experiencing?

A 64-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after experiencing sudden weakness on the left side of his body. On examination, he exhibits right-sided facial droop and difficulty moving his right eye laterally. He has also lost the ability to feel pain and temperature on the right side of his body. What type of stroke is this patient most likely experiencing?
questions.explanation:
Pontine Stroke Syndrome

Ventro-caudal Pontine Infarction

 

-Paramedian perforating arteries arising from the basilar artery.
  • Contralateral hemiparesis (corticospinal tract).
  • Ipsilateral abducens palsy (abducens nerve).
  • Ipsilateral facial nerve palsy (facial nerve).
  • Contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation (lateral spinothalamic tract).
  • Millard-Gubler Syndrome: Contralateral hemiparesis, ipsilateral abducens, and facial nerve palsy.
  • Foville Syndrome: Same as Millard-Gubler with additional conjugate gaze palsy. (Option A ruled out)
  • Raymond Syndrome: Contralateral hemiparesis with ipsilateral abducens palsy, no facial nerve involvement. (Option D ruled out)

Mid-pontine Base Infarction

 

-Paramedian arteries or short circumferential arteries, both arising from the basilar artery.
  • Ipsilateral ataxia (pontine nuclei).
  • Ipsilateral facial sensorimotor weakness (trigeminal nerve).
  • Contralateral hemiparesis (corticospinal tract).
  • Pure Motor Hemiparesis: Isolated contralateral motor weakness due to corticospinal tract infarct.
  • Ataxic Hemiparesis: Ipsilateral ataxia with contralateral motor weakness.
  • Dysarthria-Clumsy Hand Syndrome: Dysarthria, dysphagia, impaired hand dexterity, and weakness. (Option C ruled out)

Tegmental Pontine Syndrome

 

-Rostral Pontine Syndrome: Anterior inferior cerebellar artery or superior cerebellar artery.

-Caudal Pontine Syndrome: Anterior inferior cerebellar artery or short circumferential arteries.
  • Ipsilateral facial sensory disturbance (trigeminal nucleus).
  • Ipsilateral masticator paralysis (trigeminal motor nucleus).
  • Impaired blinking (tectospinal tract).
  • Contralateral hemisensory loss (medial lemniscus and lateral spinothalamic tract).
  • Ipsilateral hemiataxia (superior cerebellar peduncle).

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with severe burning pain on the left side of his body three months after having a stroke. He describes the pain as constant and stabbing, with episodes of intense shooting pain lasting several minutes. Physical examination reveals hyperalgesia and allodynia in the affected areas, with abnormal temperature sensation. MRI shows a lesion in the ventroposterolateral thalamus. Which of the following best describes this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Complex regional pain syndrome with peripheral nerve involvement

options.label: B
options.text: Dejerine Roussy syndrome with central thalamic pain

questions.correct_answer: B. Dejerine Roussy syndrome with central thalamic pain
questions.explanation:
Dejerine Roussy Syndrome

Pain Components
  • Spontaneous constant pain (burning, aching, freezing)
  • Spontaneous intermittent pain (shooting, lancinating)
  • Evoked pain (hyperalgesia, allodynia)

Pain Characteristics
  • Sharp, burning, stabbing quality
  • Affects areas corresponding to stroke
  • May be immediate or delayed up to several months

Sensory Findings
  • Abnormal pain/temperature sensation (90% cases)
  • Hyperalgesia
  • Allodynia
  • Variable touch/vibration changes

Anatomical Location
  • Primarily: Ventroposterolateral thalamus
  • Can occur with lesions anywhere along spinothalamic tract

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with progressive difficulty looking upward and complains of double vision. On examination, he demonstrates impaired upward gaze, jerky convergence movements of both eyes on attempted upward gaze, and pupils that constrict poorly to light but constrict well with near vision. He has adopted a chin-up position to compensate. MRI reveals a mass in the pineal region. Which of the following best characterizes this condition and its classic triad?

options.label: A
options.text: Paralysis of downward gaze, convergence weakness, and pineal mass

options.label: B
options.text: Paralysis of upward gaze, convergence-retraction nystagmus, and pupillary light-near dissociation

options.label: C
options.text: Paralysis of lateral gaze, retraction nystagmus, and normal pupils

options.label: D
options.text: Complete ophthalmoplegia, dilated pupils, and pineal calcification

questions.correct_answer: B. Paralysis of upward gaze, convergence-retraction nystagmus, and pupillary light-near dissociation
questions.explanation:
Parinaud Syndrome

Classic Triad

1. Impaired upward gaze (upgaze palsy)

2. Convergence-retraction nystagmus

3. Pupillary light-near dissociation

Common Symptoms

- Difficulty looking up

- Diplopia (65% of patients)

- Blurred near vision

- Oscillopsia

- Compensatory chin-up position

Additional Signs

- Collier's sign (lid retraction) in 40%

- "Setting sun" sign

- Loss of convergence (<25% of patients)

Common Causes

- Pineal tumors (most common in young)

- Midbrain infarction

- Hydrocephalus

- Multiple sclerosis

- Hemorrhage

- Infections (toxoplasmosis)

Anatomical Location

Dorsal midbrain/pretectal area at level of superior colliculus

questions.text: A 62-year-old man presents with a sudden onset of left-sided drooping eyelid and difficulty coordinating movements of his right arm and leg. On examination, he has left-sided ptosis, dilated left pupil, and the left eye is "down and out." He demonstrates significant right-sided ataxia but has normal strength in all extremities. Which of the following conditions represent the suspected diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Claude Syndrome

Anatomical Location

Midbrain (Red Nucleus Region)

Structures Affected

- Oculomotor nerve (CN III)

- Red nucleus

- Dentatothalamic tract

Ipsilateral Findings (CN III)

- Ptosis

- Dilated pupil

- "Down and out" eye position

- Diplopia

Contralateral Findings

- Cerebellar ataxia

- Limb incoordination

- No hemiparesis (key distinguishing feature)

- Intention tremor

Key Distinguishing Features

- No hemiparesis (unlike Weber)

- No choreiform movements (unlike Benedikt)

- Contralateral ataxia (unlike Nothnagel)

Vascular Supply

Paramedian branches of posterior cerebral artery

Common Causes

- Stroke (most common)

- Hemorrhage

- Tumor

- Multiple sclerosis

Syndrome

Key Manifestations

Weber Syndrome

Ipsilateral CN III palsy (ptosis, pupillary dilation) + contralateral hemiparesis (corticospinal tract).

Benedikt Syndrome

Ipsilateral CN III palsy + contralateral ataxia and tremor (red nucleus involvement).

Wallenberg Syndrome

Ipsilateral Horner syndrome, ataxia, dysphagia, and hoarseness + contralateral loss of pain/temperature.

Locked-In Syndrome

Quadriplegia and anarthria with preserved consciousness and vertical eye movements.

Millard-Gubler Syndrome

Ipsilateral CN VI and VII palsy + contralateral hemiparesis.

Raymond Syndrome

Ipsilateral CN VI palsy + contralateral hemiparesis.

Foville Syndrome

Ipsilateral CN VI palsy + contralateral hemiparesis + gaze palsy.

Dejerine Syndrome

Ipsilateral CN XII palsy + contralateral hemiparesis and impaired proprioception/vibration.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with double vision and difficulty maintaining balance while walking. On examination, she has drooping of the right eyelid, a dilated right pupil, and significant unsteadiness with right-sided limb ataxia. Unlike other midbrain syndromes, she has no weakness in her extremities. Which of the following are the structures affected?

options.label: A
options.text: Superior cerebellar peduncle and CN III

questions.correct_answer: A. Superior cerebellar peduncle and CN III
questions.explanation:
Nothnagel Syndrome

Anatomical Location

Dorsal Midbrain (Quadrigeminal Plate)

Structures Affected

- Oculomotor nerve (CN III)

- Superior cerebellar peduncle

Ipsilateral Findings

- CN III palsy (ptosis, dilated pupil, eye deviation)

- Cerebellar ataxia

- Limb incoordination

- Gait disturbance

Key Distinguishing Features

- No contralateral hemiparesis (unlike Weber)

- No tremors (unlike Benedikt)

- Often bilateral

- Commonly associated with tumors

Common Causes

- Pineal region tumors

- Quadrigeminal plate tumors

- Vascular lesions

- Multiple sclerosis

Clinical Significance

- Often presents as neuro-ophthalmological emergency

- May be first sign of pineal region tumor

- Usually requires neuroimaging for diagnosis

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents with a sudden onset of right-sided weakness and left-sided drooping of the eyelid. On examination, he has left-sided ptosis, a dilated left pupil that doesn't react to light, and the left eye is "down and out." He also has right-sided hemiparesis affecting his face, arm, and leg. Which of the following best describes this syndrome and its anatomical location?

options.label: A
options.text: Claude syndrome - Red nucleus and CN III

options.label: B
options.text: Weber syndrome - Cerebral peduncle and CN III

options.label: C
options.text: Benedict syndrome - Red nucleus and superior cerebellar peduncle

options.label: D
options.text: Millard-Gubler syndrome - Ventral pons affecting CN VI and VII

questions.correct_answer: B. Weber syndrome - Cerebral peduncle and CN III
questions.explanation:
Characteristic

Description

Anatomical Location

Ventral Midbrain (Cerebral Peduncle)

Structures Affected

- Oculomotor nerve (CN III)

- Cerebral peduncle (corticospinal tract)

Ipsilateral Findings (CN III)

- Ptosis (drooping eyelid)

- Dilated pupil (parasympathetic)

- "Down and out" eye position

- Impaired medial, upward, and downward gaze

Contralateral Findings

- Hemiparesis/hemiplegia (face, arm, leg)

- Spastic paralysis

- Hyperreflexia

- Babinski sign

Vascular Supply

Paramedian branches of the posterior cerebral artery

Common Causes

- Stroke (most common)

- Tumor

- Hemorrhage

- Multiple sclerosis

questions.text: A 54-year-old male presents with a sudden onset of double vision, left-sided weakness, and difficulty moving his right eye. On examination, the patient has a right-sided ptosis, a dilated pupil that does not react to light, and an outward deviation of the right eye. The left side of his body shows weakness with hyperreflexia. MRI reveals an ischemic lesion in the midbrain. Which of the following structures is most likely involved in this patient’s condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Trochlear nerve nucleus and Crus cerebri

options.label: B
options.text: Oculomotor nerve nucleus and Crus cerebri

questions.correct_answer: B. Oculomotor nerve nucleus and Crus cerebri

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with sudden onset right-sided weakness, inability to speak, and unawareness of his surroundings. On examination, he has complete right-sided hemiplegia, and global aphasia, and is neglecting the right side of his visual field. Non-contrast CT of the brain shows a hypodense area involving the left middle cerebral artery territory. What is the most likely type of stroke?

A 68-year-old man presents with a sudden onset of right-sided weakness and aphasia. CT angiography reveals an occlusion in one of the arteries. Which of the following best describes the location of this occlusion?
questions.explanation:
Vessel

Location/Course

Key Areas Supplied

Clinical Features When Occluded

Internal Carotid Artery (ICA)

Ascends through neck, enters skull via carotid canal

Gives rise to MCA and ACA

Large territory infarcts affecting both MCA and ACA distributions

Anterior Cerebral Artery (ACA) (Option D)

Courses anteriorly and curves around corpus callosum

Medial surface of cerebral hemisphere, anterior 3/4 of corpus callosum

Contralateral leg weakness, behavioral changes

MCA - M1 Segment

Horizontal course from ICA bifurcation to MCA bifurcation

Lenticulostriate arteries to basal ganglia

Contralateral hemiparesis, aphasia (if dominant hemisphere)

MCA - M2 Segment (Option C)

Insular segment in Sylvian fissure

Insular cortex and operculum

More restricted deficits than M1 occlusion

MCA - M3 Segment

Opercular segment

Lateral convexity of hemisphere

Specific cortical deficits based on location

MCA - M4 Segment

Cortical branches over lateral surface

Specific cortical regions

Focal deficits based on affected region

questions.text: A 62-year-old male presents with sudden onset right-sided weakness, slurred speech, and difficulty comprehending language. A CT scan reveals an ischemic stroke. The stroke likely involves which of the following vessels?

A 56-year-old man with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia is brought to the emergency department after suddenly losing vision in the left visual field of both eyes. He denies any headache, weakness, or sensory deficits. On examination, his visual acuity is intact, but he has left homonymous hemianopia. There is no evidence of motor or sensory loss. Where is the most likely site of the stroke?

A 70-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after her family noticed significant changes in her behavior and difficulty speaking. Upon examination, she displays weakness on the right side of her body and struggles to form coherent sentences, often speaking in short, fragmented phrases. The family also reports that she has become more irritable and has difficulty managing her daily tasks. What type of stroke is this patient most likely experiencing?

A 55-year-old right-handed man presents to the emergency department after his partner noticed he has been struggling to communicate effectively. He speaks in long sentences but often uses nonsensical words and seems unaware of his errors. Additionally, he has difficulty remembering recent conversations and frequently confuses familiar faces. What type of stroke is this patient most likely experiencing?
questions.explanation:
Features of Left Temporal Lobe Stroke

Features of Right Temporal Lobe Stroke
  • Impaired language and memory: Difficulty with spoken language and remembering verbal information.
  • Fluent (Wernicke’s) aphasia: Fluent speech with incorrect words, affecting language comprehension.
  • Poor visual memory and spatial awareness: Difficulty recognizing visual patterns and spatial information.
  • Prosopagnosia: Inability to recognize faces, including familiar ones. (Option A ruled out)

General Features of Temporal Lobe Stroke
  • Poor memory: Difficulty recalling past memories and learning new information.
  • Prosopagnosia: Trouble recognizing faces and objects.
  • Fluent aphasia: Specifically in left-sided strokes, affecting speech fluency but with incorrect word use.
  • Visual perception difficulties: Challenges with interpreting the visual field and surroundings.
  • Trouble processing sound: Inability to differentiate or process sounds correctly.
  • Emotional and behavioral changes: Varying behaviors due to damage to the amygdala, such as aggression, passiveness, or difficulty interpreting facial cues.

questions.text: A 62-year-old right-handed woman is brought to the hospital after her husband noticed she was having trouble writing and appeared confused about her left and right sides. Upon examination, she struggles to recognize familiar objects and is unable to perform simple calculations. Her speech is intact, but she has difficulty repeating phrases. What type of stroke is this patient most likely experiencing?
questions.explanation:
Features of Left Parietal Lobe Stroke

(Dominant)

Features of Right Parietal Lobe Stroke

(Non-Dominant)
  • Agnosia: Difficulty recognizing objects, people, or sounds.
  • Right-left confusion: Poor differentiation between right and left sides.
  • Agraphia: Difficulty with writing due to motor or memory issues.
  • Acalculia: Inability to process numbers and perform simple math.
  • Aphasia: Difficulty with speech, often conduction aphasia (speech repetition issues).
  • Gerstmann’s Syndrome:
    • Involves Angular gyrus - Brodmann area 39
    • Triad of agnosia, agraphia, and acalculia.
  • Hemineglect: Decreased awareness of the left side of the body or surroundings. (Option D ruled out)
  • Poor spatial awareness: Difficulty navigating due to spatial perception issues.
  • Impaired sense of direction and visual memory: Difficulty navigating environments.
  • Anosognosia: Inability to perceive or acknowledge stroke-related deficits.
  • Proprioception dysfunction: Difficulty sensing body parts in space, affecting balance and coordination.
  • Both lobes can also be affected, leading to further memory changes or Balint’s Syndrome (visual processing and gaze issues).

questions.text: A 67-year-old male presents to the emergency department with sudden right-sided weakness and difficulty coordinating his movements. He also reports an altered sensation on the right side. His medical history includes hypertension and diabetes. Upon examination, he shows reduced strength in his right arm and leg. What type of stroke is this patient most likely experiencing?

A 72-year-old male presents to the emergency department with sudden-onset right-sided weakness and difficulty speaking which started 2 hours ago. His medical history includes hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and a prior TIA. His BP is 180/110 mm Hg. A CT scan of the head rules out hemorrhagic stroke. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management for this patient?

options.label: B
options.text: Start intravenous heparin for anticoagulation therapy.

options.label: C
options.text: Initiate blood pressure management to lower the BP to <160/90 mmHg before considering thrombolytic therapy.

options.label: D
options.text: Begin treatment with antipyretics and surface cooling to manage fever.

questions.text: A 65-year-old diabetic male presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of right-sided weakness and slurred speech that resolved completely within 2 hours. His blood pressure is 160/90 mmHg. Based on his ABCD2 score of 6, what is the most appropriate immediate management?

options.label: A
options.text: Start oral aspirin 81 mg daily alone

questions.correct_answer: B. Combination of clopidogrel plus aspirin

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with sudden onset right-sided facial weakness and slurred speech that completely resolved within 45 minutes. Which of the following statements about this transient ischemic attack (TIA) is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: If neurological symptoms begin improving within 1 hour, it indicates TIA

options.label: B
options.text: Treatment window period from symptom onset is 4.5 hours

options.label: C
options.text: Patient has highest risk of developing stroke after 72 hours

options.label: D
options.text: Symptoms must completely resolve within 24 hours to be classified as TIA

questions.correct_answer: C. Patient has highest risk of developing stroke after 72 hours

questions.text: A 58-year-old male presents with acute left-sided weakness. MRI imaging is performed showing:  Which of the following best describes the significance of the diffusion-perfusion mismatch in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: It represents chronic ischemic changes and is not clinically relevant

options.label: B
options.text: It indicates the ischemic penumbra and potentially salvageable tissue

options.label: C
options.text: It is a marker of hemorrhagic transformation risk

options.label: D
options.text: It represents a completed infarction that cannot be salvaged

questions.correct_answer: B. It indicates the ischemic penumbra and potentially salvageable tissue

questions.text: A 72-year-old male presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of left-sided hemiplegia and aphasia. His last known normal time was 5 hours ago. CT angiography reveals a right middle cerebral artery (MCA) occlusion. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

A 65-year-old male presents with sudden onset of vertigo, dysphagia, hoarseness, and left-sided facial numbness. On examination, he has left-sided Horner's syndrome, right-sided loss of pain and temperature sensation in the body, and left-sided cerebellar signs. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 65-year-old man with a history of hypertension presents with a sudden onset of right-sided weakness affecting his face, arm, and leg without any speech disturbance. CT scan shows a small infarct in the posterior limb of the internal capsule. Which of the following vessels is most likely involved in this pathology?
questions.explanation:
Lacunar Syndrome

Location of Infarct

Supplying Vessel

Clinical Features

Pure Motor Hemiparesis

Posterior limb of internal capsule or basis pontis

Lenticulostriate arteries or paramedian pontine arteries

Face, arm, and leg weakness on one side without sensory, visual, or cognitive deficits

Pure Sensory Stroke

Ventral posterolateral nucleus of thalamus

Thalamogeniculate arteries

Hemisensory loss affecting face, arm, and leg without motor weakness

Ataxic Hemiparesis

Posterior limb of internal capsule or basis pontis

Lenticulostriate arteries or paramedian pontine arteries

Ipsilateral ataxia with contralateral pyramidal signs

Dysarthria-Clumsy Hand

Pons or internal capsule (genu)

Penetrating branches of basilar artery or lenticulostriate arteries

Dysarthria and dyspraxia of hand without significant weakness
